BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form at elevated altitudes. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2000 m and adjacent to ridgelines.
The somewhat older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Thursday. The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow.
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack, in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. Fresh wind slabs require caution. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation mostly small dry loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Avalanches can be released in near-surface layers. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in extremely steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northerly directions, small wind slabs will form in the course of the day at high altitude. These are to be avoided in particular in terrain where there is a danger of falling. Even a small avalanche can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
Hardly any more moist snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on shady slopes. Adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like.
In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was good. Wind slabs above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The hard wind slabs of recent weeks can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The mostly small wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls at elevated altitudes. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
In particular on steep slopes individual avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on weak layers. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low avalanche danger will prevail. The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
Only isolated moist avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be in most cases stable. It is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
Intermediate and high altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions are favourable over a wide area. The wind will be strong at times in some regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A mostly favourable avalanche situation will prevail. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
As a consequence of a strong wind from northerly directions, small wind slabs will form in the course of the day at high altitude. Along the border with Switzerland the avalanche danger is a little higher.
Avalanches can be released in near-surface layers in particular. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation only isolated gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible, in particular in case of releases originating from very steep sunny starting zones below approximately 2800 m that still retain some snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Until Tuesday the weather will be mild.
In particular steep south, west and southeast facing slopes,: Towards its surface, the snowpack is hard and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the old snowpack.
Below approximately 2000 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day individual mostly small snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 2000 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep sunny slopes. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. In high Alpine regions a little snow is lying. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to moistening of the snowpack at high altitude. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be stable. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in extremely steep terrain in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. Avalanches can be released in near-surface layers in particular.
This applies in particular in case of a large load. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
Hardly any more natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
In very isolated cases weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
In all regions as well as in all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low avalanche danger will prevail. The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines. Regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 2 (moderate): As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, small wind slabs will form at elevated altitudes. They can be released in isolated cases.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow fell on Thursday, in particular in the north. Over a wide area strong northwesterly wind above the tree line.

The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: Early and late morning: The old snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are favourable over a wide area. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The mostly small wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
In particular on steep slopes individual avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
In some regions only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny. The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be stable. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by people on very steep shady slopes, in particular in the vicinity of peaks above approximately 2600 m. The avalanche prone locations are very rare but are difficult to recognise.

In these regions hardly any more moist snow slides and avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In the Prealps as well as at low altitude no snow is lying. Also in neighbouring regions less snow than usual is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Until Saturday the wind will be strong at times. Moist and wet avalanches and slab avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m, also in gullies and bowls in particular above approximately 1500 m, as well as on steep sunny slopes.
Until Saturday the wind will be strong at times over a wide area. The fresh wind slabs will form in the vicinity of peaks. The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. Older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. The hard wind slabs are easy to recognise. Skiers can release avalanches only in isolated cases, including medium-sized ones. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather was mild. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The sometimes strong wind will transport only a little snow. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The sometimes strong wind will transport only a little snow.
